### 1. Introduction

Dian Fossey was an American primatologist who studied the mountain gorillas in Rwanda. She was born on January 16, 1932, in San Francisco, California. She was the youngest of three children. Her father was a lawyer and her mother was a teacher.

Fossey was interested in animals from a young age. She studied zoology at the University of California, Berkeley, and then went on to study primatology at the University of California, Los Angeles.

In 1963, Fossey traveled to Africa to study the mountain gorillas. She spent years living with the gorillas and studying their behavior. She also worked to protect the gorillas from poachers.

In 1985, Fossey was found murdered in her cabin in Rwanda. Her death was a shock to the primatology community and to the world.

David Gilmour (born 6 March 1946) is an English musician, singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and record producer. He joined the progressive rock band Pink Floyd as guitarist and co-lead vocalist in 1968. He was a member of the band for 28 years, and was credited as a co-writer for all Pink Floyd albums from 1968 to 1985. He also produced all of Pink Floyd's studio albums from 1987 to 2014.

Gilmour has also released four solo albums, and has participated in several film and theatre soundtracks. Uday Kotak is an Indian businessman and philanthropist. He is the founder and executive vice chairman of Kotak Mahindra Bank, a private sector bank in India. He is also the founder and chairman of Kotak Investment Advisors, a wealth management firm.

### 2. Early life

Audre Lorde was born in Harlem, New York, in 1934. Her parents were immigrants from the Caribbean, and she grew up in a working-class neighborhood. She was the youngest of three children.

Lorde was a lesbian and a feminist from a young age. She was inspired by the work of black feminist writers like Alice Walker and Toni Morrison. She also drew inspiration from the civil rights movement and the women's movement.

Lorde attended Hunter College in New York City, where she studied English literature. She later earned a master's degree in library science from Columbia University.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output:
Novak Djokovic is a Serbian professional tennis player. He is currently ranked world No. 1 by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP). He has won 12 Grand Slam singles titles, including a record seven Australian Open titles, three Wimbledon titles, two US Open titles, and one French Open title. He has also won a record six ATP Finals titles.

Djokovic is widely regarded as one of the greatest tennis players of all time. He has won more Grand Slam singles titles than any other active player and is the only player in the Open Era to have won all four Grand Slam tournaments at least twice. He has also won more Masters 1000 titles than any other player in the Open Era.

Djokovic has been ranked world No. 1 by the ATP for a record 311 weeks, including a record 223 consecutive weeks from 2011 to 2016. He has also been ranked in the top 10 for a record 350 weeks.

### Answer

Indira Gandhi was the first and only female Prime Minister of India. She was born on 19 November 1917 in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh. She was the daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru, the first Prime Minister of India. She was married to Feroze Gandhi, a journalist. She had two sons, Rajiv Gandhi and Sanjay Gandhi.

Indira Gandhi was a strong leader who led India through difficult times. She was known for her tough stance on foreign policy and her support for the poor and downtrodden. She was also known for her strong personality and her ability to make tough decisions.

Indira Gandhi was assassinated on 31 October 1984 by her own bodyguards. She was succeeded by her son, Rajiv Gandhi, who became the Prime Minister of India.

Rosa Luxemburg was a Polish-German Marxist theorist, philosopher, economist, and revolutionary socialist. She was a leader in the Social Democratic Party of the Kingdom of Poland and Lithuania and the German Social Democratic Party.
